title.narrative: KEWASNET: förbättrad styrning i kenyanska vattensektorn
KEWASNET: improved governance in the Kenyan water sector

description.narrative: Kenya Water and Sanitation Network (KEWASNET) program Water Sector Governance Support programmet tar avstamp i den konstitutionella rätten till vatten och sanitet i Kenya och avser att stärka deltagande, styrning och ansvarstagande av myndigheter och regeringen på lokal och nationell nivå inom vattensektorn. Insatsen kombinerar en nedifrån och upp ansats med kapacitetsuppbyggnad på lokal nivå för att hålla länsregeringar och vattenbolagen ansvariga, med en nedifrån och upp ansats med fokus på advocacy, fortsatt sektorreform och kunskapsspridning på nationell nivå. I utvalda län kommer dessutom budgetanalyser göras för att kunna rapportera på ett genomlysande sätt vad pengarna inom sektorn används till. Civila samhället inom vattensektorn kommer stärkas. Insatsen kompletterar annat stöd inom vattensektorn till statliga myndigheter rörande tillhandahållande av service på lokal nivå genom WSTF (Water Services Trust Fund) genom sitt rättighets- och deltagande perspektiv på lokal nivå. KEWASNET som nätverk har verkat i flera år och är en erkänd NGO aktör inom vattensektorn, men som autonomt nätverk endast i lite mer än 1 år och institutionella svagheter har identifierats i en utvärdering och den externa finansieringen är begränsad. Programmet löper i 3 år och tyngdvikt under det första året ligger därför på att bygga upp sekretariatet för att KEWASNET ska kunna uppfylla sitt mandat, utöka sin närvaro nationellt och även kunna hantera och attrahera ytterligare medel.

The purpose of the project is to strenghten CSO participation in the WASH sector in Kenya in order to secure better governance and sustainable delivery of water and sanitation services to the poor and underserved.

sector.narrative: Education and training in water supply and sanitation

tag.narrative: 6.a - By 2030, expand international cooperation and capacity-building support to developing countries in water- and sanitation-related activities and programmes, including water harvesting, desalination, water efficiency, wastewater treatment, recycling and reuse technologies.

6.a - Till 2030 utöka det internationella samarbetet och stödet för kapacitetsuppbyggnad till utvecklingsländerna inom vatten- och sanitetsrelaterade verksamheter och program, inklusive genom tekniker för vatteninsamling, avsaltning, vatteneffektivitet, rening av avloppsvatten, återvinning och återanvändning.

title.narrative: Decision Amendment KEWASNET Förbättrad Styrning i Kenyanska Vattensektorn

description.narrative: Outcome 1: Improved Citizen Participation in WASH service delivery and WRM sector decisions - Increasing engagement by KEWASNET’s partners in decision-making processes at national and county level, with evidence of duty bearers being more accountable and responsive to the needs of the citizens in terms of access to WASH. - Capacity building efforts through study circles and learning forums in four regions supported reaching over 200 members and partners in South Rift, Nairobi, North Rift, Western/Nyanza and the Coast regions. The learning programmes focussed on e.g. Pro-poor Units at water companies, Integrity Management for three WSPs (Oloolaiser, Lodwar and Wajir). KEWASNET ‘s capacity building efforts were further increased though the development of social accountability tools with the support of other programmes (Watershed and Danish People s Aid) to complement the already existing knowledge base. - Through policy development efforts in Kisumu, Uasin Gishu, Kiambu, Kajiado and the development of the Framework for monitoring “Realization of the Right to Water and Sanitation in Kenya” with KNCHR , KEWASNET engaged with government offices, and agencies to help them to increase citizen participation; be socially inclusive; and be accountable and transparent in planning, budgeting, monitoring and implementation. - The policy influence demonstrated that when government understands these changes are necessary to achieve sustainable WASH for all, they will listen to CSOs and coordinate with other government offices, and agencies. The policy development support to County governments has been an important point of reflection and learning with regards to how to involve citizens in governance. KEWASNET is documenting the best practices for the development of policies at County level, and anticipate that this will become a point of reference for other partners. Outcome 2: Improved Sector Decision-Making and Resource Allocation - KEWASNET launched the third consecutive CSO report in April 2017 to provide the government and the public with summarised information on CSOs’ Water, Sanitation, Hygiene (WASH) and Water Resources Management (WRM) activities, outcomes and performance. This year’s report also included assessing the environment in which CSOs operate, mainly to understand if the weak CSO performance is linked to weak governance across the sector particularly pertaining to issues of corruption. In line with this CSOs estimated that 10% of project funds were lost due to corruption, amounting to approx. 300 Million KES during the past financial year. This substantiates the weaknesses in the incentives, regulations, and control mechanisms to ensure accountability of water sector CSOs. - KEWASNET finalised the budget tracking briefs from Isiolo, Turkana and Garissa, carrying out joint public participation meetings at county level and budget advocacy initiatives. The studies examined the financial flows, the county budget and expenditure on different water activities over FY 2013/2014 and 2014/2015, and analysed key governance issues. KEWASNET and partners sought to mobilise capacitated partners to carry out effective advocacy towards attaining increased budget allocations and more solid oversight of how funds are spent. Outcome 3. Improved Sector knowledge in Key WASH and WRM issues - In November 2016, KEWASNET co-convened with Ministry of Water and Irrigation and development partners the 1st Kenya Water Week 2016 (KWW) which included the MaPia2016 awards (Water Performance and Innovation Awards). MaPIA recognized and rewarded the most outstanding innovations in the WASH sector that have contributed in the achievement of Kenya’s WASH goals under Vision 2030 and the Sustainable Development Goals. - KEWASNET also restructured its digital platform and revamped its website to accommodate the Virtual Resources Centre. KEWASNET received a bid on documentation but is currently consulting with GIZ IWASP on the development of this component. Additional efforts included the development of the KEWASNET newsletter. Outcome 4: Strong, Responsive and Effective WASH Sector - Based on the assessment of the VIWANGO certification, KEWASNET finalised on key policies identified by the assessment creating an enabling environment for improved decision making and performance, these include: Partnership Policy, Conflict Policy, Resource Mobilisation Policy, ICT Policy, Political Neutrality Policy and the Gender Policy. KEWASNET inducted the staff on improving gender mainstreaming across the programme and the organisation, this includes e.g. changes in the selection of participants in trainings and meetings, better representation of women and youth (whether as panellists, participants or support to meetings). KEWASNET has equally been active in the Women and Water partnership and integrating gender and WASH. - In June 2017, KEWASNET signed the MOU with WSTF: Reaching the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and the Human Right to Water and Sanitation for rural areas and small towns. At the end of the three-year time-frame the expectation is that in addition to results in increased citizen participation, WSTF will be better positioned in terms of management, strategic direction, performance monitoring of rural water and sanitation and WRM projects.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
